required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Reducing Obesity Among Public Housing Residents: an Ecological Approach
clinical_study.official_title: Reducing Obesity Among Public Housing Residents: an Ecological Approach

collaborator.agency: National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute (NHLBI)

brief_summary.textblock: The obesity epidemic disproportionately affects the 1.2 million U.S. households living in public housing, where nearly 50% of adults are obese and have a two-fold greater risk of hypertension. Using an ecologic framework, we propose that neighborhood social network factors likely promote unhealthy lifestyle behaviors that contribute to this disparity. The overall objective of this proposal is to identify social network factors that promote healthy diet, physical activity and healthy weight among public housing residents. We focus on the social network - the connections among people within a community - as theoretical work suggests that social networks have an important influence on health behaviors. However, no previous studies have examined lifestyle behaviors in a social network analysis or targeted these behaviors with a social network intervention. Our aim for this work is: 1) To develop a social network intervention to facilitate lifestyle behavior change and pilot test it in residents of public housing developments as in Baltimore, MD. We hypothesize that a social network intervention will be feasible and acceptable in promoting healthy lifestyle change, and that this intervention will alter lifestyle behaviors among public housing residents.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in healthy eating index score among alters
Change in eating behavior inventory score in alters
Change in Baecke exercise scores among alters

primary_outcome.description: Satisfaction with intervention will be assessed among participants or egos using a 4-point Likert scale.
We will calculate the average number of group intervention sessions attended.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- At least 18 years old
- BMIâ‰¥25 kg/m2
- At least one and up to three of their overweight risk alters identified in the social network analysis must also enroll
- Resides in public housing in Baltimore, MD
Exclusion Criteria:
- Any underlying medical conditions that could seriously reduce their life expectancy, their ability to participate in the trial, or for which lifestyle change may be contraindicated and/or require medical supervision by a physician such as medication-dependent diabetes mellitus, cancer, lung disease requiring supplemental oxygen, dementia, angina, or diagnosis in the last 12 months of myocardial infarction, transient ischemic attack or stroke

facility.name: Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine
